body:
Bisect NPM:
1.40.0-alpha-oct-25-2023 bad
1.40.0-alpha-oct-24-2023 good

RANGE: https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/compare/fe7847b126ce2059d02fbbbc1f632b04fdae3ef7...0bb9f7cdf7367185c89a24305ca21d0768e5d54f

Looks caused by https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/pull/27762

@agoldis This is an intended change. After A fails, B is not run at all, so we do not produce a "skipped" run. Would you like to still see a skipped run for B? What's the reason? Please provide as much details about your usecase as you can.

_Would you like to still see a skipped run for B?_

- Yes, if that's possible, I understand there may be many reasons not to keep the original behaviour, but I believe `1.39` was handling serial groups more correctly, at least from a reporter author perspective.

_What's the reason?_

- It's inconsistent with `1.39` and produces different results
- Test `B` only runs once and never retries, although we set `retries: 1`
- It doesn't match the documentation
  - https://playwright.dev/docs/test-parallel#serial-mode
    - >... if one of the serial tests fails, all subsequent tests are skipped.
  - https://playwright.dev/docs/test-retries#serial-mode
     - > ...If one of the tests fails, all subsequent tests are skipped
  - I read `skipped` as getting status `skipped`, while `1.40` simply doesn't run the test. But maybe I am mistaken, please correct me.
 - It is impossible (to my best knowledge) for reporters to interpret what actually happened - `1.40` produces one attempt for test `B` with retry index `0`. A reporter would register the following results in `onTestEnd`:  `A - 0: failed, 1: passed`, `B - 0: failed`  so it may seem as if both `A` and `B` ran one after another as part of the same serial "attempt", which isn't supposed to happen. In other words, reporters can't "register" the fact that some tests in a serial group were skipped because of a preceding test failure. `1.39` was triggering both `onTestBegin` and `onTestEnd` for skipped serial tests and that was working great! 

I hope it makes sense... We just need a clear way to identify what happened when interpreting results in a reporter. 

P.S. 

Looking at the fix at https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/pull/27762 and the original issue at https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/issues/27455, I think the real issue is how PW detects flaky tests. 

That's why I also opened https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/issues/28322. I understand it is a disruptive proposal, but let me try.

I think a test should be marked as flaky if and only if:

- `expectedStatus` is not `skipped` and
-  non-skipped and non-interrupted attempts have 1 status that matches the `expectedStatus` and one that doesn't

For example, `1.39` marks the following test with 'expectedStatus: passed' and 4 attempts: `skipped, failed, skipped, failed` as flaky, however, all the executed attempts produce similar results: `failed`, so I would not consider this test as flaky. 

Sorry for my ignorance, may be I am missing something - I am new here.

We decided to revert #27762 for now. However, the definition of a flaky test must differentiate between tests skipped with `test.skip()` vs tests skipped because of serial mode failure or any other similar scenario. Otherwise, it does not work in some of the cases. We'll think more about it.

issue.title: Revert "chore(test runner): remove fake skipped test results (#27762)"

repository.name: playwright
repository.description: Playwright is a framework for Web Testing and Automation. It allows testing Chromium, Firefox and WebKit with a single API.

body:
Thanks for the quick turnaround @dgozman!
Exposing something like a skipped cause or a new status would do the job. I would be happy to contribute if you provide a direction.

issue.title: cherry-pick(#28360): Revert "chore(test runner): remove fake skipped test results (#27762)"
